Understanding Patents For Your Business

What is a Patent?

A patent is a legal instrument issued by a government that confers to the inventor of a product the sole right to exploit it, that is manufacture, use, sell or dispose of the product for a limited time of 20 years. This means that for this period of time no other person or firm can legally make use or even sell the invention in question without the consent of the patent holder. Patents can be sought for all manner of inventions, including new technologies and methods, products and materials, design, and chemicals.

The heart of a patent is said to be in its barring of others from generating revenue from the invention in question. It makes inventors disclose their inventions to the public to receive a temporary exclusive right over the invention. After a certain time has elapsed, normally the period of validity of the patent, the invention becomes free for anyone to use.

Importance of Patents in India

The world’s largest democracy and a rapidly growing economy, India is now a fertile ground for innovation. In this context, the role of patents cannot be deemed to be insignificant. Here’s why patents are vital in India: Here’s why patents are vital in India:

  1. Encouraging Innovation:

It is worth noting that patents are important in the sense that they give an inventor the desire to invent. Since inventors understand that their inventions will be protected, they are willing to devote their time, capital, and effort to the development of these technologies.

  1. Economic Growth:

Businesses gain from these patents by the promotion of a competitive business environment hence enhancing the economic growth of the country. Currently, when firms are assured that their products’ innovations will not be emulated by the competitor firms their production will be improved hence advancing the economy’s technology.

  1. Attracting Foreign Investment:

The author noted that a rather well-developed patent regime is essential to entice foreign direct investment. Businessmen who have interests in expanding into the Indian market are keen to know that their ideas and brands are protected. This security is offered by a robust patent regime making India a better place for foreign investors and players.

  1. Promoting Knowledge Sharing:

Patents give protection to the inventor, at the same time, inventions foster the dissemination of information. Consequently, with the grant of a patent, the technical details of the invention are published and made known to the public so that others can use the invention as a basis for further innovations.

  1. Strengthening India’s Global Standing:

A good patent regime assists in improving the position of India in the world of innovation. The protection of the rights of inventors may help India to advance its image on the world stage as a technological superpower.

The Indian Process of Filing a Patent Application

The action on the patent in India involves several actions and a proper knowledge of the legislation on the subject. Here is a simplified overview of the patent application process in India: Here is a simplified overview of the patent application process in India:

  1. Conducting a Patent Search:

There is always a need to conduct a patent search before applying for a patent so as to confirm that the invention to be patented is new and not already patented. It is useful in preventing any issues, legal or otherwise, and secures the invention to fit the requirements of a patent.

  1. Drafting the Patent Application:

The second preparation phase is to write the patent application After the non-obviousness of the invention has been defined then the next task is to prepare the patent application. Part of the information that must be provided in this document is the description of the invention together with details of its construction, operation and use. The application form also contains a section of claims that states exactly what protection under the said patent the applicant is seeking.

  1. Filing the Patent Application:

This patent application is to the Indian Patent Office as provided under the Indian Patents Act and rules. Currently, the application may be made either in person or through electronic means. While filling up the application it is required to ensure that all the documental evidence necessary for the application including the specifications, claims, drawing (where necessary) and abstracts must be enclosed in the application.

  1. Publication of the Patent Application: Publication of the Patent Application:

Following the submission of the application, the same is published in the official patent journal, which is normally 18 months from the filing of the application. The invention is disclosed publicly by the publication but the applicant retains the ownership of the invention.

  1. Examination of the Patent Application: Examination of the Patent Application:

After the publication, the application is reviewed by the patent examiner to determine whether the application meets the requirements of the patent law and regulatory provisions such as novelty, non-obviousness and industrial use. There may be an objection by the examiner, to which the applicant has to respond.

  1. Grant of Patent:

If the application satisfies the examination stage and all the objections are met, then the application is granted the status of a patent. The inventor is now protected by the law and has a monopoly over the invention for a determined period.

  1. Post-Grant Procedures:

This is a fee that has to be paid periodically by the patentee to maintain the validity of the granted patent. Also, this patent can be freely passed on to others; the license can also be sold or transferred.

Patent Application

The procedure for obtaining a grant of an Indian patent is characterized by several formalities being followed to ensure compliance with the statutory criteria for the grant of a patent. Here’s an overview of the key steps involved: Here’s an overview of the key steps involved:

1. Conducting a Patent Search

When planning to file a patent application there is always a need to undertake a patent search first. This search assists in establishing whether the invention has not been invented before and hence the possibility of being patented. In the patent search, it is necessary to compare the invention with the patents granted, the published applications for a patent, and other materials that might have a bearing on the patentability of an invention. This step is necessary in order to maintain a certain distance not to violate some finer points of the Law on Inventions, and to guarantee that the invention meets the requirements of novelty.

2. Drafting the Patent Specification
  • The next stage is the preparation of the patent specification which is a legal document containing a full description of the invention. It has to present particular details about the invention and the technical and possible uses of the invention invention. It should be written in clear simple language so that when read one can understand the invention as it is. The specification is divided into two parts: The specification is divided into two parts:
  • Provisional Specification: This is a priority application that now allows an initial description of the invention to be offered. The filing of a provisional specification provides the applicant with priority or one year to file for a complete specification.
  • Complete Specification: This is the last written numerical document that presents every aspect of the invention in full detail and contains claims that state the extent of the patent protection that the inventor seeks.
3. Filing the Patent Application

An application for the grant of a patent can be made through the online mode or in physical mode at the Indian Patent Office. The specification of the application as well as other documents such as the drawings if any, the abstract and the necessary forms must be included in the application. The filing date is essential since it defines the priority of the invention…

4. Disclosure of the invention matter to the public when the patent application is published

After the filing of the application, the same is usually advertised in the official patent journal 18 months from the date of filing of the application. The information on the invention contained in the published application is made available to the public but the invention belongs to the applicant.

5. Analysis of the patent application

After the publication process, there is the examination of the patent application via a patent examiner at the bureau. The examination is carried out with the aim of making certain that the invention is sufficient protection for it to merit a patent and all its parameters pertaining to novelty, non-obviousness and industrial use or application. Objections may be raised by the examiner to facts or with regard to a particular aspect of the application and these may be responded to in writing by the applicant or amendments to the application filed.

6. Grant of Patent
  • As the case may be, if the applicant is able to pass through the examination stage and all the objections that may be raised have been dealt with, the patent is granted. A patent grants entitlement to the patentee to prevent the unauthorized usage, selling and manufacturing of the invention.
  • Some of the considerations that an applicant must make include the following;

When filing a patent application, several key considerations can significantly impact the outcome: When filing a patent application, several key considerations can significantly impact the outcome:

  1. Clarity in Drafting the Specification: Clarity in Drafting the Specification:

The specification has to be prepared with such a level of detail that the nature of the invented object should be clear and the inventor should not be able to omit anything. It can entail problems during the examination process or restrict the range of protection, if there are uncertainties or gaps.

  1. Timely Filing:

Filing the patent application at the earliest is very important to obtain an early priority date. This can be quite useful where two or more firms are working in different but competitive invention projects.

  1. Addressing Examiner’s Objections:

 

When making the examination, the patent examiner may object to the novelty, inventive step, or industrial use of the invention. One has to be able to address these objections and state the needed clarification of the points or a revision of the claims to fit with the criteria.

  1. Maintenance of the Patent:

After the patent is issued, it has to be ‘renewed’ periodically by making relevant payments towards renewal fees. These fees must be paid to avoid the expiry of the patent thus the exclusive control of the invention.

What is Patent Filing?

It is a process whereby an individual applies to a patent office to seek legal protection for his or her invention. This step is important to enable the inventor or the applicant to have exclusive control of the invention where no other person is allowed to make, use, or sell it without the consent of the inventor or applicant. In the case of the business entities and the inventors, an application for seeking a patent is an important tool in their armoury to safeguard the property of the innovations created by them and in addition to that sustain a competitive advantage in the market.

Patent Filing Process: Filing a patent is essential for several reasons: Filing a patent is essential for several reasons:

Legal Protection: After the filing of the patent and after it has been granted, the inventor is given legal backing. It implies that the patent owner can sue anybody who uses the patented invention.

Market Exclusivity: Patents provide the inventor with a legal monopoly to exploit the invention commercially in the marketplace.

Monetization Opportunities: A patent gives a lot of opportunity to the inventor as the inventor can license out the technology to others or sell outright the patent.

Increased Valuation: To the business entity, the acquisition and development of a strong patent undertaking can act as a booster in the enhancement of the worth of the company to its investors and partners.

  • Some of the activities that go into filing a patent include fundamentals of patenting procedures and patent prosecution costs.

Filing a patent involves several key steps, each of which must be carefully followed to ensure the application is successful: Filing a patent involves several key steps, each of which must be carefully followed to ensure the application is successful:

1. Conduct a Patent Search:

When seeking to get a patent for an invention it is good practice to carry out a patent search to ensure that the invention doesn’t have a previous patent. This step assists in preventing possible legal disputes and also makes the invention so developed to qualify for a patent.

2. Prepare the Patent Application:

The next process is to prepare the patent prosecution document also known as the patent application. This document is an extended description of the invention with drawings if needed and the claims that will describe the protection that is being sought. The application could be a provisional application in which an early filing date is obtained or a non-provisional application containing full description of the invention.

3. Submit the Patent Application:

However, this must be done after the application has first been prepared to be submitted to the relevant patent office. This in the case of India would be the Indian Patent Office. Application can be made online or on paper and the date of application is very important as it determines the application’s standing in terms of priority of invention.

4. Examination Process:

They go through an examination stage where a patent examiner conducts a search in order to ascertain that the application meets all legal provisions. This involves having a verification of the invention for novelty in addition to the invention’s non-obviousness or inventive step as well as industrial applicability.

5. Addressing Objections:

The applicant is allowed to respond to any issues that the examiner may have with the application by making some explanations or changes. Thus, one could conclude that the main reason for successfully coming through the mentioned stages is the ability to meet the objections that follow.

6. Patent Grant:

Thus after all the objections have been addressed the invention is deemed to have complied with all the requirements and thus a patent is given. This provides the patent holder monopoly over the invention for a particular time – usually, 20 years from the date the application for the patent was filed.

Tips for Successful Patent Filing
  • Be Thorough:

In addition, there are certain recommendations required to be followed while filing the patent application, that an applicant should be very professional and specific. Legal descriptions are specific and thus minimise the possibility of objections and move the approval faster.

  • Consult an Expert:

Patent law is tricky. A patent attorney is also beneficial in this process to lead the way and avoid common pitfalls that will lead to the rejection of the application.

  • File Early:

Indeed, timing is everything in the world of patents. Filing early means your invention will be protected by a priority date and it gives you a head start against your competitors.

  • Maintain Your Patent:

Patents need regular upkeep. This is crucial to remember, as it is easy to have your rights taken away if you do not pay for maintenance on time – but do not worry, it’s not all for nought if you have been putting in the effort:

  • Use Online Registration:

The procedures for the registration of patents in the online platform are however speedy and efficient. It can assist you to apply faster, keep the application organised, and monitor all processes without any difficulties.

What is Patent Opposition?

What is Patent Opposition?

Patent opposition is in essence a legal process whereby third parties are allowed to neutralize the grant of a particular patent or a patent application. This mechanism is very important in a way that only meritorious inventions which have the potential to be unique in the market will be granted protection by the patent system. Patent opposition is a legal proceeding where if a person feels that a patent ought not to have been granted – say because the invention is unoriginal, obvious or does not have a practical use in industry – they can file an opposition

The following are some of the reasons that Patent Opposition is very important:

Opposition is a crucial part of ensuring that there is credibility regarding the matters of patents. Here’s why it matters:

Prevents Unjust Patents: It assists in preventing the grant of patents on inventions that do not satisfy the legal requirements, nature, quality or kind such as novelty or non-obviousness.

Protects Public Interest: In so doing, it opens an opportunity for third parties to oppose what they consider to be unjustified patents in order that the general public is not unduly fettered.

Encourages Fair Competition: For it protects individual companies from monopolizing markets through patents that ought not to have been issued in the first place, it encourages competition.

Types of Patent Opposition

There are two main types of patent opposition: There are two main types of patent opposition:

  • 1. Pre-Grant Opposition

Opposition may occur before the grant of the patent where it takes place after the publication of the application but before the patent is issued. It also permits any third party to object to the application on a variety of pre-scribed grounds such as novelty or obviousness. This process assists in the elimination of applications that should not go to grant.

  • 2. Post-Grant Opposition

Opposition takes place after a grant of the patent has been awarded but before the grant of a certificate of infringement or registration of the patent. Every year any interested person may appeal against the grant of a patent in the belief that it was wrongly granted. If so it results in the cancellation or alteration of the patent.

The main activities that occur in the course of patent opposition include the following:

Here’s a quick overview of the steps involved in opposing a patent: Here’s a quick overview of the steps involved in opposing a patent:

  • 1. Filing the Opposition Notice:

The opposition process starts with the filing of a notice of opposition. The facts and allegations on which the opposition of the patent is based are described in this document and the opposition has to be supported within the given period.

  • 2. Submitting Evidence:

This one is presented with details from both sides; the opponent and the patent holder produce evidence. This finally comes with the opponent substantiating evidence on why the patent should not be issued, while the holder of the patent responds to the points of the opponent.

  • 3. Hearing:

Inter-party hearings may be conducted where the two parties or either of them may call on the patent office to advance arguments. This is also a chance to explain certain matters and answer the questions, the examiner might have.

  • 4. Decision:

Finally, the patent office makes a verdict after going through the proofs and the arguments and presenting them. Based on the realizations the patent may be sustained, altered, or cancelled.

What is Patent Litigation?

Litigation involves the legal procedures that follow, once one party feels that the other is violating their patent rights. This usually entails a patent infringement case under which the owner of the patent takes the other party (the infringer) to court for using, creating or distributing an invention or goods under the patent without the approval of the owner. 

Litigation plays the most significant function in the enforcement of the patent and making sure that the persons who own these patents enjoy their monopoly on inventions for a particular period.

Patent disputes are important for the following reasons

Another patent status is that litigation is essential in the protection of patent rights. Here’s why it matters:

Protects Intellectual Property: It enables the patent holders to exercise their rights in relation to the inventions and bar people from using their inventions without permission.

Deters Infringement: The existence of a patent lawsuit may discourage others from deploying a technology that could violate a patent hence preserving the integrity of the patent.

Ensures Fair Competition: Patent law and litigation thus contribute in ensuring that no competitor gains an undue advantage in the market through copying the work of others but only entices the market through rewarding the innovators.

The Patent Litigation Process

Patent litigation involves several key stages, each designed to resolve disputes over patent infringement: Patent litigation involves several key stages, each designed to resolve disputes over patent infringement:

  1. Filing the Complaint:

The procedure starts under the assumption of the patentee who files a patent infringement suit in a court of law. The complaint provides information on the patented invention, the infringement of the patent, and the prayer which can be in the form of damages and or an injunction restraining the defendant from continued infringement of the patent.

  1. Discovery:

Discovery is the process by which both parties to the case assemble supporting evidence for the case’s allegations. This phase is usually characterized by the interchange of documents, deposition and assessment of a patent as well as the derivate product or service that is under scrutiny.

  1. Pre-Trial Motions:

During the pre-trial stage, the parties may CC some motions in the trial to endeavour to solve certain problems or even have the case thrown out. Other motions are those in support of a motion for a summary judgment whereby a party will pray for the matter to be decided without any trial on the basis of the facts.

  1. Trial:

In the case of trial, the lawyers of both parties make their arguments and bring in their evidence and witnesses including the experts. The court then goes ahead to decide if the defendant has indeed infringed on the patent rights of the plaintiff and if so, the court is then called upon to determine which remedy is to be provided.

  1. Post-Trial Motions and Appeals:

Post-trial after the rendition of a verdict, a motion can be made to vacate the verdict or change either the judgment or verdict. If the motions are denied, the party that was adverse to it can move to the appellate level to seek a review.
